data.note: The regulatory framework allows for private entities to apply for a power distribution licence.  To date, this has been used by PowerHive, which plans to build and operate 100 mini-grids in partnership with Italy-based utility Enel. There are other small mini-grid operators that work without formal regulatory approval. Regulations for self-consumption of power are very light-handed.
data.name: Mini-grids: licensing

data.note: PowerHive has a power distribution license. However, this does not grant the company exclusive rights over specific areas.
data.name: Mini-grids: concessions

data.note: Under the 2015 Energy Bill, a licence is required for any generation capacity. Self-consumption under 1MW does not require a license.
data.name: Mini-grids: threshold

data.note: Project developers have to deal with a variety of agencies. The Energy Regulatory Commission maintains a website that outlines the licensing process and provides relevant documentation. http://www.renewableenergy.go.ke/index.php/search/licensesearch.
data.name: Dedicated regulator

data.note: There is no dedicated team.
data.name: Dedicated team within utility

data.note: The regulatory framework requires no licensing for self-consumption projects under 1MW. Retailing power from a mini-grid requires a distribution license as well as agreement on a tariff.
data.name: Light-handed regulatory framework

data.note: Mini-grid developers that obtained a distribution license would have to comply with the regulated tariff structure for grid power. Any deviation from this needs to be negotiated with the government and regulator.
data.name: Cost reflective tariffs

data.note: Regulated on-grid tariffs are reviewed regularly. A feed-in tariff lasts for 20 years and is set in nominal terms with only a partial escalator. It is therefore likely to decline in real terms.
data.name: Stable tariff guaranteed

data.note: The current regulation requires independent power distributors to adhere to the regulated retail tariff. PowerHive is likely to establish a precedent should the regulator agree differential tariffs for mini-grids.
data.name: Tariff deregulation

data.note: The Energy Regulatory Commission provides a power purchase agreement (PPA) template on its website. Developers say that some of the template terms are not bankable and require renegotiation.
data.name: Standardised PPAs

data.note: The PPA terms are 20 years.
data.name: PPAs of sufficient duration

data.note: The PPA template states that the buyer will purchase the net electrical output as ascertained by the metering equipment. The PPA template also contains a clause allowing the buyer to interrupt or reduce offtake under certain conditions. Developers report that these terms are not bankable and have been amended for some projects.
data.name: Purchase obligation

data.note: The PPA template states that the seller must, at its own expense, design, purchase, construct, operate and maintain the interconnection facility.
data.name: Clear rules on interconnection

data.note: The PPA template states that the seller must, at its own expense, design, purchase, construct, operate and maintain the interconnection facility.
data.name: Clear rules on arrival of the main grid

data.note: Plans are reportedly being made available to interested parties as they are developed.
data.name: Transparent grid extension plan

data.note: The Electricity Licensing Regulation specifies the terms and service level for any power distributor. Mini-grid operators seeking to retail electricity fall under this license as well.
data.name: Quality of service standards

data.note: Kenya is one of the hotbeds of innovation in pay-as-you-go solar. M-Kopa, the leading distributor, has been adding a variety of other products for which it provides consumer financing, using a solar home system as collateral.
data.name: SPPs can deliver financial services

data.note: Kenya's Rural Electrification Agency was established under the Energy Act of 2006 and became operational in 2007. Kenya aims to reach 100% electricity access by 2020. Its electrification rate rose from 26% in 2012 to 47% by mid-2015, supported by several programmes that are electrifying schools and reaching households located close to existing transformers.
data.name: Rural electrification program

data.name: Rural electrification agency

Its electrification rate rose from 26% in 2012 to 47% by mid-2015, supported by several programmes that are electrifying schools and reaching households located close to existing transformers.
data.name: Energy access targets (general)

data.note: The Rural Electrification Agency and Kenya Power already operate several islanded mini-grids in areas considered too remote to be connected to the grid.
data.name: Offgrid energy access target

data.note: Private companies such as SunFunder and various others provide financing to off-grid solar companies operating in Kenya, one of the most highly penetrated markets in the world.
data.name: Offgrid financing facilities

data.note: There are three subsidy mechanisms for household electrification in Kenya: 1) The World Bank's International Development Association (IDA) reimburses Kenya Power for connections to households in informal settlements at a rate of KES 1,160 ($11.45) per connection; 2) 'StimaLoans' are offered by to customers requiring financing for grid connections; and 3) Under the Last Mile programme the African Development Bank provided $139.5m of finance in FY2015/16 to subsidise connections to households within 600 metres of a transformer.
data.name: Connection grants

data.note: There are no other incentives for off-grid projects or mini-grids.
data.name: Other off-grid incentives

data.note: An amendment to the VAT code in 2014 specifies that "specialised solar equipment and accessories, including solar water heaters and deep cycle-sealed batteries, which exclusively store solar power," are VAT-exempt. Power generation equipment is exempt from import tariffs, as is PV equipment. Applications running on their own source of power, such as solar lanterns, are subject to a 10% import tariff.
data.name: Tax / duty reductions

data.note: The World Bank's Lighting Global programme has an active presence in the country. It is also home to multiple NGO-driven off-grid programmes.
data.name: Off-grid market building

data.note: There are several PAYG providers active in Kenya.
data.name: PAYG availability

data.note: Kenya does not apply its own quality standards. The World Bank's Lighting Global programme has quality standards and is very active in Kenya. Distributors of quality-verified solar kits say that generic products are commonly available and counterfeits are a problem.
data.name: Pico-solar quality standards

data.note: Gasoline and kerosene are VAT-exempt.
data.name: Kerosene and diesel subsidies
